poem:
### Battle Cry in Govan

Sweaty fingers trace the line  
between peace and silvered fear—  
Govan's heart beats with iron truth,  
war forged in the nuclear whisper.  
Shipyard ghosts in riveted prayer  
murmur through corrugated souls,  
hard power on the brink of thunder,  
and an unspoken hope for rain.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "To the ramparts! Sir Keir summons hard power for hard times | John Crace It’s War-War. Keir Starmer had come to the Govan shipyard to get us battle ready. The threat was real. The threat was now. His sweaty fingers hovered over the nuclear button. Any minute now he could authorise a first strike. Possibly by mistake. The world had never been more dangerous. It had taken all his self-restraint not to come dressed in". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
